Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: An Outsourced and Completely Private Social Network: You&Me
Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, any data posted or stored on the existing social networks are visible to the social network providers. Once a user posts a message or stores personal information on a social network, it is no longer in the control of the user how the data will be used by the social network service providers. In the past few years, many media organizations have been arguing that certain providers are probably selling user profile data to third-party advertisers to make profits. In the wake of such criticisms, users become more concerned about their privacy leaving them with a serious question as to whether or not any social network provider can be seriously trusted. Since the user profile data reside on the servers of a social network provider, there is no way for a user to verify whether the provider is strictly enforcing the user's privacy policies.

The I-Corps team is currently working on a prototype system of You&Me. It combines the secure techniques generated from the principal investigator's previous research project, the existing open source database management systems, and open source user interface development packages to implement You&Me. So far, the team has finalized the basic software architecture and components and started implementing the fundamental features. At the end of this project, the team expects to have the basic version of the prototype system as a demo. The prototype system will show potential investors how You&Me can fully protect user privacy, and at the same time, the users can still enjoy the same or very similar functionalities as the existing social networks.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to personal privacy concerns, online social or communication networks have provided various options for a user to guard or control his or her personal data. However, since user data are stored on the network server, the data are still accessible by the network administrator, which can lead to both liability issues if data breach occurs at the server side and data misuse by the network administrator. Privacy issue also comes from the third-party applications running on the social network that keep track of user network data. To protect user privacy, there is a strong demand to develop a secure or privacy-preserving social network that can be theoretically proven to protect user data from the network administrator and other social network users.

This project investigated the challenges to commercialize such a privacy-preserving social network through extensive interviews among potential users. The findings further confirm the initial assumption that social network users do care about their privacy. At the same time, preserving their social network circle is also very important. Thus, in addition to privacy protection, other incentives are needed to attract people to use a private social network. The project provided graduate students invaluable experiences related to technology transfer and entrepreneurship, and it also created timely opportunity to discuss the importance of personal privacy and data security with K-12 teachers through the GenCyber security summer camp at Missouri S&T.

 


Last Modified: 08/15/2016
Modified by: Wei Jiang
